captions.text:
Whaddap whaddap? This week on Thug
Notes it’s gettin hella hot with Dante’s Inferno

Dante must have blacked out or
something cuz dis fool lost in the woods and
don’t even know how he got there.

He keeps truckin along til three gnarly beasties
start mad doggin him. sh**’s bout to get

real til
the poet Virgil saves his ass and tell him

he been sent by his old biddy Beatrice who
boppin up in heaven.

Dante starts trippin when he hears
the screams of da Uncommitted- peeps who didn’t

do sh** with their lives. But his guide, Virgil,
tells him to stop being a bitch and start
their journey through the 9 circles of Hell.

After gettin straight clocked out,
Dante wakes up in Limbo- the first circle.

This hood filled with all da righteous souls
who lived before Christianity or never got
they selves baptized.

The second circle be full of
lustful peeps who just couldn’t keep it

in their pants. Up in here, Minos sorts all
dem sinners in to the right circles.

Up in the third circle be all the
gluttons.

Whether it be sippin too much
drank, blowin too much dank, or grubbin too
hard, all deez fools gettin served by Cerberus.

The fourth circle packed with all
dem greedy shysters who don’t do nothin

but chase paper. And the fifth got all da
wrathful souls scrappin on the surface of
the Styx river.

Then our hero rolls up to the city
of Dis. Behind these walls lie homies who

dun REALLY fu**ed up. In the sixth circle,
Dante peeps all the heretics get lit up in
red-hot sepulchres.

The seventh circle spillin over
with homies who been violent towards others,
themselves, and God.

Then Dante and Virgil hop on a
three-headed monster called Geryon, who takes

em to Malebolge- the eighth circle. This crib
sportin all dem fakers who been frontin with
magic, astrology and otha sh**

Then our boys swang over to the ice-
cold 9th circle of Hell; where Satan himself

be torturin all them snitch traitors of history.
Virgil and Dante decide they gonna peace out
and slide down The Beast’s body to Purgatory.

This poem be the first part of
Dante’s three-part Divine Comedy. But it
ain’t called a comedy cuz Dante got jokes. You see me laughin?

Most scholarly hoods point out that
literary comedy starts out with some real

twisted sh** but ends up all good in the hood.
And Dante’s whole shebang starts off in
Hell and ends in Paradise.

Listen up blood cuz Dante layin all
sorts of allegory on yo bitch ass. On one

level, The Inferno representin all the temptation
mankind gotta rough through in order to find
salvation.

Dante trying to find God thinkin it
ain’t no thang, but the true path blocked

by three slobberin beasts. And dem haters
symbolize all the sins Dante gotta overcome
he can smoke and sip with the big G.

But dat ain’t the only allegory
Dante pimpin. Not only is he talkin spiritual,

but he also talkin political. See in 1302,
Dante got stright exiled outta Florene during

a coup. And as a result, fool was just sliding
aimlessly from spot to spot for the rest of
his days.

So the dark wood that Dante gets lost in not
only representin his

spirit searching for God, but also his wandering
days after gettin exiled.

But of all historical poets, why did Dante
choose Virgil to guide him through the underworld?

Well
back in the day, Virgil wrote bout how Troy’s
fall led to the establishment of Rome.

And just as the beginning of the
Trojan’s journey to Rome was a raw grind,

Dante had to man the fu** up and roll through
Hell and Purgatory before getting to Heaven.

Hey thanks for kickin it with your
boy. Don’t stop reading and check me out
next week.

title: Dante's Inferno - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.text:
Is The Devine Comedy a difficult read? How does it compare in difficulty 
to, say, Shakespeare?﻿
comments.author: Boxjuice

comments.text:
+Boxjuice the hardest thing about it is the historical references... 'weird 
as hell' in a visual way, it does a great, unique job at describing hell, 
but each layer is filled with sinners with historical examples of this ho 
and that traitor so you might not know who certain tax evader or heretics 
are, but it's pretty easy to appreciate in literary terms and might make 
you interested in history without bogging you down in having to agree with 
(or necessarily know about) dante's judgments of his peers... it kind of 
reads like a gossip-rag alice in wonderland if you don't take it as 
gospel-truth indictment, but it is pretty even when it's horrifying which 
is pretty weird

comments.author: Bryan McCormick

comments.text:
Purgatory (Lat., "purgare", to make clean, to purify) in accordance with 
Catholic teaching is a place or condition of temporal punishment for those 
who, departing this life in God's grace, are, not entirely free from venial 
faults, or have not fully paid the satisfaction due to their transgressions.
comments.author: dtt1900

comments.text:
+Greg Frazer You're not far off. Purgatory is a mountain that goes from 
earth (right above the entrance to hell) to heaven. I'ts the place people 
go when they've sinned, but can still make things right by paying pennance. 
After they've payed proper pennance for what they've done, they're 
eventually allowed in heaven. There's no ghosts there, though. Just souls 
like in heaven and hell. I'm not sure, but I don't think ghosts where a 
thing back then. I think everything was more black and white and all you 
had was variations of demons and angels.

comments.text:
This comment is from my own knowledge, correct me if I'm wrong!
But during the writing of the Divine Comedy, religion was a HUGE factor. 
Like, if you weren't Christian in some way, you were weird. If you look 
more into Dante's life, you can see that he really hated backstabbers, and 
heretics and magic was considered a power against the church, which was no 
good. This writing isn't something that is true throughout time, but is 
very important in literary history and just because he believed certain 
things belonged in hell more than others, doesn't mean they are the worst 
crimes, even though many still believe they are pretty bad.
comments.author: NinjaDownYourStreet

comments.text: +Damon Morris catholic means universal
comments.author: Mystery

comments.text:
Just a heads up when you're talking about being Christian you might want to 
say Protestant (A lot of what the US follows diff  denominations)

A lot of the social systems in the present do not hold the same amount of 
water that many who practiced Roman Catholicism in Italy during Dante's 
time. In many ways the RC was much more publicly seen as a power hierarchy 
to rule over communities not just in Rome but in other parts of the HRE 
(Holy Roman Empire) before the 1517 Reformation by Martin Luther.  In 
respect to Florence just look up Girolamo Savonarola. There was so much 
social power during that day.
comments.author: sintofg

comments.text:
I normally dont comment, but let me interject for one moment. the writtens

that it shows is dante's creative license. now, the church did use this 
work, but that was mainly for propaganda to keep the believers docile and 
obedient.
comments.author: Ethan Green

comments.author: alexandra thomas

comments.text:
Dante's Comedy is very, very allegorical, and incorporates elements from 
other religions, mainly classical and nordic paganism.  While it's still 
centered in Christianity, it derives more from myth and oral tradition than 
scripture.
comments.author: Wolfgang Amadeus

comments.text:
Roman Catholicism is a branch, not the tree. The word "Catholic" means 
being one with God. So it was universally used by all followers until the 
word "Christian was invented." Which in Greek means follower of Christ. The 
word 'catholic' means universal. There is no evidence that the very early 
Christians called their religion 'catholic'. The term 'Catholic' may have 
come into use in the second or third century by the orthodox Christian 
Church, as a reaction against Gnostic Christianity. The Roman Catholic 
Church, as we know it today, is arguably the product of the Great Schism of 
1054.
comments.author: Damon Morris

comments.text:
+Damon Morris
It'd be more accurate to say Roman Catholicism is the tree that the other 
ones branched off of...

sep·ul·cher
ˈsepəlkər/Odoslať
noun
noun: sepulchre
1.
a small room or monument, cut in rock or built of stone, in which a dead 
person is laid or buried.
synonyms: tomb, vault, burial chamber, mausoleum, crypt, undercroft, 
catacomb; grave
"an old family sepulcher on the grounds of the estate"

comments.text:

comments.author: Leonard Lopez

comments.text:
The book is called the Divine Comedy; the Inferno is the first of three 
realms - Hell (Inferno), Purgatory (Purgatorio) and Heaven (Paradiso), 
which Dante and his guides travel through in the afterlife.

comments.text:
That was good. One tiny little critic though. The three-headed dog is 
pronounced Kerberus (hard k) NOT Cerberus even though that is how you spell 
it. I just always cringe a little inside when people get that wrong. Sorry 
for being nit-picky ﻿
comments.author: TheOnlyMonkeyDragon

comments.text:
+TheOnlyMonkeyDragon there is religious subtext to the arguments the 
grown-ups are having about the pronunciation of that letter. Or at least 
there was before all the grown-ups died. Now their parrots are flapping 
around making confused attempts at arguing with each other.... To put it as 
simply as I can, the pope says it's a soft c.
It's not really important. I doubt that any of our Latin teachers would 
even be intelligible to the ancient romans. The real question at stake over 
the letter c in latin is about authority and loyalties and passive 
aggressive stubbornness. Its about how you see the language and the issue 
of setting the record straight, or "correcting" the language to some 
particular date.

When it comes to the pronunciation of a specific proper noun, unless you 
have some ethical stand you want to make, just roll with the prevailing 
pronunciation, and opt against saying "aaaaaactually....." Because it would 
probably be no less accurate to say cheerbaydaws.
comments.author: Pete Van Horn

comments.text: I am Italian and trust me.. It's Cerberus with a soft c
comments.author: Christian Prandi

comments.text:
+Joe Verlander Yeah well several Latin (the language) teachers says that is 
how it is pronounced. The original Greek and Latin way of pronouncing 
Cerberus is with a K sound.  It how is was meant to be pronounced. However 
as with many things the English speaking community has mispronounced it for 
so long that it has become the common English way of saying it. Much like 
selfie is now an actual word. 

Also it originally stems from old Greek and Roman mythology were it would 
sound more like this :http://www.pronouncenames.com/search?name=Cerberus  

http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Kerberos 

Also since we are talking about the actual mythological creature and not 
some english rip-off slang. I would say that pronouncing the name like it 
is supposed to is preferable to the English version. Were they just said 
fuck other cultures we will just pronounce it like this.

comments.author: saintlallaward

comments.text:
They call me the Unglum Pussy Professor 'cuz I school cats for the sheer 
fun of it.
If you wanna peep the strategy of Inferno then you gotta get to numbering 
what's under it. Dante's pilgrim pride is just a whack emcee without his 
guide. But why call in the pagan squadrons of bards from Limbo's secret 
garden in the midst of a benediction of Christian metaphysics? Terza rima 
didn't just rhyme for the cynics, it wasn't just political business, and 
there's also the problem of our unreliable witness. So check it: the Aeneid 
deals with the aftermath of the Trojan war & sh*t. Ostensibly, it's an 
historical justification of the Roman Empire, commissioned by Octavian 
Augustus after he seized the regime; Virgil's own stance on the legitimacy 
of both Octavian's empire and Empire as such is just out on the block, but 
that cold emcee shoots the trees with the breeze by re-branding the Greek 
gods to stand in for his bastard manager's daddy's iffy-lineage, so Julius 
Caesar (and thus Octavian) flex demigod status over any plebe who steps to 
mess with 'em. (Tho on the upside, when you got thugs on the block, weaker 
thugs on the next block think twice about reppin') by tracing their fateful 
from Venus , who the Greeks called Aphrodite (or something like it. You 
gotta squeeze The Aeneid like a pimple on the skin of Dante's Inferno with 
at minimum two fingers, man: Dante uses Virgil as a character in his 
Inferno to guide the not-so-anonymous pilgrim through Hell; but Virgil, 
snatched the break-stick from his own predecessor, Homer, depicting the 
main character, Aeneas, squirming like a worm through the underworld in 
Book VI. So rack 'em. We back to Greek tongues and out of Latin ones when 
the blind bard depicted Odysseus' communing with the dead to gank the 
scraps of forgotten prophets. Now your best dressed but still stubbly 
addressor personally tends toward a reading of Inferno that reconfigures 
the reading of both Virgil and the apocalyptic tradition of the prophetic 
books of scripture, particularly Ezekiel 2-4, in order to synthesize the 
discourse. "Digest my word," says Virgil to his boy-toy Dante in Inferno: 
the heads who contend to lead the dead with prescient vocal embers will 
remember how Ezekiel's eating of the scroll and the order that he bake his 
bread on a fire of human dung -- we ain't gotta tell you where it's comin' 
from, but thread the needle into the sequel. We taste dread vowels 
sandwiched by nouns' bread -- on the reg -- or else it's all in our heads. 
& yes yes y'all. & you don't stop. 

Here's a free audio version of John Dryden's translation of Virgil: 
https://archive.org/details/aeneid_0810_librivox1, and here's a printable 
text version of it: http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/228.﻿
